explanatory comments/crosstagging: Lisa Trivedi has shown that a black-and-white version of this print graced the cover of a Gandhian publication in 1922 (Trivedi, Lisa. 2003. Visually Mapping the Nation: Swadeshi Politics in Nationalist India, 1920-1930. Journal of Asian Studies 62 (1):11-41; see pp. 17-18). Note the fact that the flag shown in this print is fairly close to Gandhi’s design (originally created by one of his followers Venkayya and adopted in 1921) although the latter had a purple spinning wheel. According to Gandhi, “the weakest numerically occupy the first place, the Islamic colour comes next, the Hindu colour comes last, the idea being that the strongest should act as a shield to the weakest." (Quoted in Singh, K. V. 1991. Our National Flag. New Delhi: Publications Division, Government of India, p. 37. Compare this figure with figure 30 where Lord Krishna is shown blessing the Gandhian spinning project. (Sumathi Ramaswamy) (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: A striking example of Gandhi’s prominence in this print culture from the Priya Paul Collection is the image in Figure 18, possibly from the early 1920s, that focuses centrally on a relatively youthful Gandhi—possibly a recycled image from a photograph—who is shown being blessed by the figure of Mother India, who despite a halo around her head, could also pass for the Every Woman of the emergent nation. She grasps the Gandhian flag in one hand, while the other holds the thread that connects to a spinning wheel prominently on display at the bottom of the print. Of critical important here is the visual suggestion that as the wheel turns it creates the nation, signified by the outline map of India and titled in Hindi as “Bharat.” This image (and others like it) seems to suggest that the very map of India is a product of Gandhian labours—rather than of colonial state science—as the Mahatma literally spun the nation into existence. (Sumathi Ramaswamy) (gs)
